newsitem.title: UK: Lanica says share suspension to continue.
newsitem.headline: Lanica says share suspension to continue.

text.p: Lanica Trust Ltd, the Guernsey-based investment trust run by entrepreneur Andrew Regan, said on Monday the suspension of its shares on the London Stock Exchange would continue until CWS's private prosecution against was resolved.

Lanica's shares were suspended at 19.50 pounds on February 10 when its emerged that its offshoot Galileo was attempting a 1.2 billion pounds ($2 billion) takeover of the Co-operative Wholesale Society (CWS), a move which collapsed in April.

The takeover for the supermarkets-to-funeral parlours group collapsed after CWS succeeded in blocking the attempt through the courts and a key financial backer for Galileo, Regan's special bidding vehicle, withdrew its support.
"We are naturally disappointed that Galileo was not able to proceed to put its proposals to the members of CWS," Regan said in a statement.
"We believed very strongly that these were in the best interests of Lanica Trust's shareholders, but equally importantly, to the owners of CWS. However, it was not to be".

Lanica said that Regan and his business associate David Lyons both "confidently expect" the Serious Fraud Office investigation into a previous deal between CWS and Regan's Hobson Group to exonerate the Hobson board.
The investigation centres on the circumstances of a controversial contract and payment of 2.4 million pounds agreed between CWS and Hobson in January 1995.

Lanica also reported its annual results which showed a loss for the group in the year to December 31, 1996 of 381,045 pounds, compared with a surplus of 578,456 the year before. It said that excluding the write-off of Lanica's investment in Galileo, the total surplus was 220,899 pounds.
